'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.proactiveinvestors.co.uk/companies/news/1052079/ftse-100-live-shares-fight-back-as-pound-hits-year-high-on-cpi-us-tech-sell-off-1052079.html', 'title': 'FTSE 100 live: Shares fight back as pound hits year high on CPI, US tech sell-off', 'body': 'FTSE 100 climbs 18 points to 8183 HSBC promotes CEO from within King\'s speech main takeaways 2.44pm: US big tech-driven slide\n\nUS stocks have started mainly lower, led by the tech megacaps.\n\nThe S&P 500 has fallen 0.93% and the Nasdaq has plunged 1.7% in early trading, while the Dow Jones initially slipped lower, it quickly rebounded up 0.10%.\n\nAmong the big techs, Nvidia is down 1.6%, Microsoft down 1%, Alphabet down 1.4%, Meta down 1.3%, AMD down 1.3%.\n\n1.52pm: Oil helping the FTSE\n\nShell and BP are both in the green, which is helping the FTSE inch higher.\n\nThis is on the back of oil prices climbing, with Brent crude rebounding from recent month lows, up 0.66% today to $84.28, while WTI is up 0.9% at $81.48.\n\nJPMorgan has just put out a note on oil prices.\n\n"We estimate the equilibrium price of WTI oil at around $70/bbl," the investment bank\'s energy analysts say.\n\nAccording to a Reuters report, JPMorgan believes that even at $60 a barrel, WTI prices are too low to incentivize production, potentially leading to a spike to $100 per barrel next year.\n\n1.40pm: We are so back\n\nThe FTSE 100 is back in the black, perhaps picking up some of that money flowing out of the US techs.\n\nLondon\'s blue-chip index is up just six points but it\'s a start.\n\nWater and other utility companies and precious metals miners are topping the leaders, the latter helped by gold hitting new highs around $2,480 per oz.\n\nCigarette maker Imperial Brands is up 1% despite the King\'s speech bringing back Rishi Sunak\'s progressive ban on smoking.\n\nThe FTSE 250 is still chugging lower, down 117 points or 0.55% at 21,096.\n\n1.24pm: Red tape haters hate red tape shocker\n\nIn a surprising turn of events, the free market think tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs (IEA), has criticised the new Labour government\'s proposals for more regulation, though they do like the idea of looser planning laws. :\n\n"The King\'s Speech promises several welcome measures to get Britain building and growing again, particularly measures to enable more infrastructure and housing. The biggest handbrake on growth is undoubtedly our broken planning system," said Tom Clougherty, IEA executive director.\n\nHe questioned the government\'s rhetoric on growth as "much of the agenda pushes in the opposite direction" as "pro-growth measures risk being held back by new red tape and risky \'mission-led\' central planning".\n\nHe reckons the ban on new North Sea oil and gas will "hamstring Britain\'s recovery from the energy crisis" and new regulations on the labour market "will reduce flexibility and increase structural unemployment", while the smoking ban "takes away freedom from future adults while risking the creation of a mass criminal black market".\n\nTobacco group Imperial Brands\' shares are up 1% though.\n\n1.10pm: AI bill\n\nThe King\'s speech shows sends a clear message from new PM Keir Starmer: "no more light-touch regulation on AI", says Michal Szymczak, head of AI strategy at IT consultancy Zartis.\n\n"But are we throwing the baby out with the bathwater here? The new government\'s approach to AI regulation is going to be a heavier hand - maybe too heavy," he says.\n\n"It appears intent on aligning the UK\'s approach on AI intervention more closely with the EU\'s AI Act.\n\n"Given how rushed this bill was, the wisdom behind any attempts at this parity is questionable at best."\n\nSzymczak says his research has shown there\'s "considerable appetite" from UK tech leaders for greater regulatory intervention on AI, but he cautions that "any such policies could smother AI innovation in the crib with red tape", especially for startups.\n\n1.06pm: Retailers response to speech\n\nResponding to the King\'s speech, British Retail Consortium CEO Helen Dickinson says the industry welcomes bills to reform the Apprenticeship Levy and planning laws; to tackle retail crime and antisocial behaviour; and to accelerate the country\'s clean energy transition.\n\nThe employment rights bill has been a clear area of concern for some companies, with its proposal to introduce day-one rights for unfair dismissal, ban zero-hours contracts, enhance redundancy protections, ban \'firing and rehiring\' staff under less favourable terms and conditions, improve statutory sick pay and the minimum wage, and repeal the Strikes Act, which allows some employers to compel employees to work during a strike.\n\nOn the employment rights bill, Dickinson says: "The retail industry supports the goal of the Eployment Rights Bill, including making work pay, enhancing employment rights, and banning exploitative practices.\n\n"There are three million retail workers in the UK, and a further 2.7 million in the supply chain, and we look forward to engaging with the government as it carries out its consultation on the Bill to ensure the plans are practical and workable for businesses and employees."\n\n12.45pm: London shares falling as US futures point lower\n\nThe FTSE 100 is skedaddling lower again, as US futures point to sizeable falls, led by tech worries over new China sanctions.\n\nA broad sell-off is expected on Wall Street, with futures for the tech-heavy Nasdaq down 1.6%, with S&P 500 futures down 1.05% and for the Dow Jones down 0.3%, while the Russell 2000 is seen falling 0.8%.\n\nIn London, AstraZeneca, Rolls-Royce and Experian (LSE:EXPN) among the larger blue-chip fallers, all down more than 1%, with Antofagasta the biggest faller, down 4.6% after the copper giant trimmed its guidance.\n\nLife insurers and other financials are also among the fallers, including L&G and Intermediate Capital.\n\nThe FTSE 250 is also on the slide, down 0.7% to the Footsie\'s 0.3%.\n\nGenus, the sexed bull and pig semen provider, is down 8% now after its trading update warned of persistently soft demand in China and Brazil.\n\nPolar Capital Technology Trust PLC (LSE:PCT) is another faller in the mid-cap index, after reporting good final results, boosted by the \'Magnificent Seven\', with the trust returning 40.8% and beating the benchmark return.\n\nHowever, several big trusts with big tech holdings are down, including Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust PLC (LSE:SMT) and Allianz Technology Trust PLC (LSE:ATT).\n\n12.07pm: Pensions issue?\n\nThere was a notable absence of a pensions bill in the King\'s speech, says Myron Jobson, personal finance analyst at Interactive Investor.\n\nThe full text of the King\'s speech does mention a "pension investment" bill, which is thought to mean the draft audit reform and corporate governance bill, and pension schemes bill.\n\nJobson says there was a notable omission of detail "especially concerning the Labour government\'s manifesto pledge to conduct a pensions review to improve outcomes for savers and increase investment in the UK market" but it "could mean that more time can be allocated to ensure that any reforms are well thought out and pass the sniff test with key stakeholders in the pension sectors".\n\nHe notes that the speech sets out the government\'s broad legislative agenda, but doesn\'t include every policy, with more detailed financial measures and announcements to be unveiled in the next fiscal event, though Chancellor Rachel Reeves has promised to provide an update before the autumn.\n\nHelen Morrissey, head of retirement analysis at Hargreaves Lansdown, says the King\'s speech did allude to an aim to tackle the \'lost pots\' problem by automatically bringing together individual\'s deferred small pots into one place.\n\nShe says the news "heralds positive news for people\'s pensions, with simplicity and greater flexibility".\n\nShe adds: "Government estimates that the introduction of these measures could boost the average person\'s pension pot by 9% over the course of their career."\n\n11.58am: King\'s speech headlines\n\nThe King\'s speech is over, with King Charles having read out the main plans of the new Labour government.\n\nHe said that the government intends to be "mission-led and based upon the principles of security, fairness and opportunity for all".\n\nA bill will be introduced to set up Great British Energy to accelerate investment in renewable energy, a "new deal for working people" ending zero-hours contracts, and ending the exemption from VAT for private school fees to fund more new teachers.\n\nThe new Labour government will legislate to bring rail services into public ownership, and introduce an English devolution bill, giving powers to local councils to take control of their bus services.\n\n"Legislation will be introduced to give greater rights and protections to people renting their homes, including ending no fault evictions and reforming grounds for possession" the King also said.\n\nAn AI regulation bill was also announced, while Starmer\'s party is also reviving the crackdown on smokers and vapers, alongside a potential ban on energy drink sales.\n\n"A Bill will be introduced to progressively increase the age at which people can buy cigarettes and impose limits on the sale and marketing of vapes," the King said.\n\n11.38am: FTSE in the green\n\nThe FTSE 100 has turned positive, just. The index is up just over one point at a little above 8166.\n\nOnly two of the top 10 blue chips are in the red, while top of the leaderboard are Barclays PLC, up 2%, Endeavour Mining PLC (LSE:EDV, TSX:EDV, OTCQX:EDVMF), up 1.7%, and BT Group PLC, up 1.6%.\n\nLondon\'s mid caps are still in the red though, with the FTSE 250 index down 89 points or 0.4% at 21,125.\n\n11.21am: European inflation still \'relatively benign\'\n\nEurozone inflation came in at 2.5% for June, a dip from 2.6% the month before, matching the consensus and first estimate.\n\nThe core rate was stable, at 2.9%, also matching the consensus.\n\n"All eyes are on persistently sticky services," says Claus Vistesen, economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, as still-high inflation remains in insurance, package holidays, hotels & accommodation, social protection, refuse collection and repair services adding up to inflation around 4%.\n\n"Looking ahead, a number of near-term upside risks loom," he says, with France\'s energy inflation to be lifted in July by a hike in the distribution costs of gas, the summer Olympics likely to lift inflation in French services, and Taylor Swift\'s July tour across European major cities looms as "further upside risk to inflation in hotels and other accommodation".\n\nBut even when we add these to our forecasts, however, we still see a relatively benign next few months. We think headline inflation will be unchanged in July, before falling to around 2% in August, as base effects in energy shift. This should help get a September rate cut over the line. In the core, we think services inflation will dip by 0.2pp in July, to 3.9% -- with prices rising by 1.2% m/m -- before advancing to 4.1% in August as the boost from the summer Olympics kick in. Risks to the July number are tilted to the upside mainly due to hospitality. In non-energy goods, meanwhile, we look for further disinflation in coming months, with inflation dropping to 0.4% in July and further to just above zero in August. As a result, our preliminary forecasts suggest that core inflation will dip to 2.7% in July, and further in August, to 2.6%, again supporting a second rate cut in September.\n\nThe first chart shows that still-hot services inflation remain the key driver of overall inflation in the Eurozone. This will remain the case for the foreseeable future. The second and third chart plots two of the key components in services, helping to keep inflation elevated. Insurance inflation ticked lower in June, but the trend is still shooting higher. In hotels and restaurants, inflation has come down significantly from a peak, but it remains elevated and near-term risks are tilted to the upside.\n\n-------\n\n11.08am: Fashion deal\n\nVF Corp (NYSE:VFC, ETR:VFP) has sold its streetwear band Supreme to Italo-French sunglasses maker EssilorLuxottica for $1.5 billion.\n\nVans and Timberland owner VF, which bought Supreme for $2.1 billion in 2020, decided to offload the brand following a review of its portfolio that found "limited synergies.\n\nEssilorLuxottica chief executive Francesco Milleri and deputy Paul du Saillant said they saw an "incredible opportunity to bring an iconic brand" into the company, saying it offers "a direct connection to new audiences, languages and creativity,".\n\nSupreme used to be a supercool skating brand when launched in the 1990s, but has lost its edge as it expanded into a global \'urban\' brand.\n\n10.42am: Amazon wins UK union battle, but faces legal challenge\n\nAmazon has won its UK unionisation battle by a tiny margin, with the GMB union saying the tech giant "fought dirty" with a "culture of fear" and the battle "is not over".\n\nOut of the 2,600 workers who voted at the Coventry warehouse site, 49.5% backed union recognition.\n\nThe US corporation said: "Across Amazon, we place enormous value on engaging directly with our employees and having daily conversations with them. We value that direct relationship and so do our employees."\n\nThis is a big contrast from the statements from GMB, which says Amazon now faces a legal challenge over its union-busting tactics, with reports that workers had been bombarded with what the union called an "unrelenting campaign of anti-union messages by company bosses, including multiple anti-union seminars and threats to terms and conditions" to pressure workers into cancelling their union membership.\n\nStuart Richards, a GMB senior organiser, said: "We\'ve seen workers pressured into attending six hours of anti-union seminars on top of the fortune spent by Amazon bosses to scare workers.\n\n"Workers have been told they will get no pay rise this year and will have to lose even more benefits if they vote for union recognition."\n\n10.10am: Trump lays out Fed plans\n\nDonald Trump has stated he will not seek to remove Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell before his term ends and would consider JPMorgan boss Jamie Dimon for Treasury Secretary if he wins the November 5 election, according to a Bloomberg interview.\n\nPowell\'s term expires in 2026, and his Fed Board seat in 2028. The interview was conducted in late June.\n\nPowell confirmed on Monday he plans to stay until his term concludes, having been chosen by Trump to lead the central bank in 2018.\n\nTrump later criticised Powell over interest rate hikes and apparently contemplated firing him, though aides advised he lacked the authority.\n\n9.57am: Adidas, Tiktok, Github and SpaceX\n\nHere\'s a few stories from some well-followed overseas companies.\n\nAs its collaboration with controversial musician Kanye West comes to an end, Adidas AG has raised its full-year sales guidance after posting its first annual loss since 1992 earlier this year.\n\nThe German sportswear giant had a long-running sneaker collaboration with the rapper known as Yeezy, terminated in the wake of a raft of antisemitic statements, with the last remaining Yeezy stock sold at cost and contributing to around €50 million in profits in the second quarter.\n\nGitLab, the software developer part-owned by Google, is exploring a sale and has reportedly attracted interest from potential buyers.\n\nThe company is working with investment bankers on the process.\n\nPotentially good news for TikTok, as Donald Trump expressed support amid potential bans if its Chinese parent company ByteDance does not divest its US assets.\n\nIn a TV interview, Trump emphasised the need for competition, contrasting TikTok with Facebook and Instagram. Despite previously labelling TikTok a threat, Trump joined the platform recently.\n\nAnd last and by many means least, Elon Musk has confirmed the for-some-time-expected relocation of his X/Twitter and SpaceX businesses to Texas - with a dig aimed at California\'s Democrat state governor Gavin Newsom.\n\nCommenting on California\'s new rules relating to the disclosure of child gender identity in schools, Musk posted on his X platform "this is the last straw".\n\n9.40am: Pound hits year\'s high\n\nThe only major currency to rise against the US dollar this year is the pound, analysts have noted.\n\nLast week, on the back of a better-than-expected GDP update the sterling hit a four-month high after the inflation numbers.\n\nToday, GBP/USD is up 0.35% at 1.3019, up 2.5% over the past six months, and also up 0.2% versus the euro today at 0.8388.\n\n"Not bad for the emerging market North Atlantic peso eh?" exclaims market analyst Neil Wilson at Finalto, who called the CPI data "slightly warmer than expected".\n\nHe notes that traders say this is not enough for an August cut, with bets pared on an August cut down to 25%, in line with the comments from BoE rate-setters Jonathan Haskel and Huw Pill, who both recently indicated the MPC would hold fire for now.\n\n"Gilt yields rose, with the 2yr rising 4bps to above 4%, which has helped put a bit of a bid into sterling.\n\n"The inflation data definitely supports a stronger pound narrative at this stage," adds Wilson, adding that a breach at $1.30 this morning "could then see the stage set for a run to the July \'23 highs at 1.31" and if we this occurs "we should consider a new trading range for the pound between $1.30 and $1.40".\n\nHe adds: "We should not discount the effects of the politics on this - as discussed before the new govt introduces - for now, in the eyes of investors at least - a degree more clarity and consistency in terms of policymaking.\n\n"There is clearly a reset and people are looking at the UK with fresh eyes."\n\n9.20: Mid-morning update\n\nLondon\'s blue-chip index was down 23 as UK inflation remained in line with the Bank of England\'s 2% year-on-year target last month.\n\nThe consumer price index rose 0.1% over the month of June, as expected, which meant the annual rise in CPI remained at 2.0% for the second month running. That might postpone an interest rate cut until September, economists suggested\n\nHSBC has gone in-house for its new chief executive with finance chief Georges Elhedery appointed to the role of group chief executive. Shares in the Asia-focused bank barely moved on the announcement.\n\nAll eyes now will be on Keir Starmer\'s plans as his first King\'s speech is read out with housing, labour laws, railways and his predecessor\'s smoking ban set to feature.\n\nThe speech is due to begin around 11.25am, with the House of Commons reconvening at 2.30pm for a debate on what was confirmed - read what to expect here.\n\n8.40am: H&W creaking\n\nBelfast shipbuilder Harland & Wolff Group Holdings PLC is apparently teetering on the verge of collapse as Labour prepares to reject a £200 million government loan request.\n\nAccording to a Financial Times report, Labour will refuse to act as guarantor to the critical funding, with one Whitehall figure calling it a "deeply irresponsible" use of the public purse.\n\nThe company is seeking a £200 million facility from UK Export Finance to keep the business afloat.\n\nEarlier this month, the group warned that its "ability to execute new and large contracts would be adversely affected" should it fail to secure the lifeline.\n\n8.26am: London stocks battling for position\n\nBoth the FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 have started on the back foot, but have bounced slightly from their initial lurches lower, down 0.1% and 0.2% respectively.\n\nMiners and financials are weighing on the blue-chip index, with Legal & General, Intermediate Capital, Aviva and some investment trusts mingling with the likes of Antofagasta, which is bottom of the list, down 2.9%, and Glencore, down 0.8%.\n\nAntofagasta said its full year production will be at the lower end of our guidance range of 670-710,000 tonnes, with cash cost guidance adjusted, with lower grades at its Los Pelambres and Centinela copper mines.\n\nHSBC shares are down slightly, 0.16%, on the back of the internal promotion as its new CEO.\n\nBabcock is down 1.6% after cutting its profit guidance due to a £90 million loss on a Royal Navy contract.\n\nGenus, the animal genetics company, is the biggest faller on the mid-cap index, down 4.5% despite reporting underlying profit slightly ahead of previous guidance in February.\n\nAnalysts at Peel Hunt note that volumes at its ABS bovine genetics arn have continued to be weak, while currency headwinds are likely to result in a £5 million impact.\n\nAfter the UK inflation reading earlier, the market is now pricing a 33% probability of an August rate cut, and a 74% September probability.\n\n8.05am: FTSE opens lower\n\nThe FTSE 100 has defied predictions and opened in the red after an inflation reading that was not as good as expected.\n\nLondon\'s blue-chip index started 17 points lower at just under 8148.\n\nMiners Antofagasta, Glencore and Rio Tinto are among the bigger fallers.\n\n7.59am: Babcock cuts profit guidance\n\nBabcock International PLC (LSE:BAB) has cut its profit guidance for the past year after taking a £90 million loss on the deterioration of the Type 31 warship contract.\n\nBased on draft preliminary accounts, the defence contractor said it now expects to report an underlying operating profit of roughly £238 million for the year to end-March 2024, up 34% on the prior year.\n\nThis includes a £90 million loss on the Type 31 contract and a £17 million profit on disposal of a property, while overall group revenue was up 11% to £4.4 billion.\n\nBabcock said underlying free cash flow of £160 million was significantly ahead of expectations.\n\n7.41am: Inflation views\n\nViews from the City seem to be that the Bank of England\'s monetary policy committee (MPC) is still far from definitely cutting rates next month, but confidence is growing for a September cut after this morning\'s UK inflation data for June came in with headline CPI at 2.0% year on year, core CPI at 3.5% and services CPI at 5.7%.\n\n"More tellingly the month-on-month CPI data was up just +0.1% (headline) and +0.2% (core) suggesting that the earlier Q2 price increases due to big indexation events - including a 9.8% rise in the National Living Wage - are beginning to dissipate," said Panmure Liberum economist Simon French.\n\n"Recent MPC commentary has shifted the likelihood of an August rate cut down from 65% to 50%. That feels about right on a reading of MPC members - if not necessarily our reading of the data."\n\nAndrew Summers, chief investment officer at Omnis Investments, said there is "no smoking gun for an August move", even though speeches from the MPC\'s Haskell and Pill last week reduced the odds of a move from the BoE in August somewhat.\n\n"This dataset is unlikely to turn that around, with the market continuing to focus on the meeting after, in September which is pretty much priced for a 25bps cut," he says.\n\nMonica George Michail, economist at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, said CPI inflation remaining unchanged at 2% is "good news" but the elevated rates of core and services inflation are "possibly prompting the Bank of England to remain cautious with regards to interest rate cuts".\n\nNIESR expects inflation to creep up throughout the rest of the year, before falling back towards the BoE target in early 2025.\n\n7.26am: HSBC appoints new CEO\n\nHSBC Holdings PLC (LSE:HSBA) has promoted finance chief Georges Elhedery to the role of group chief executive, after Noel Quinn\'s surprise retirement announcement in April.\n\nElhedery joined the Asia-focused lender in 2005 and after roles including co-CEO of the Global Banking & Markets division, became group chief financial officer in 2023. He will take on the CEO mantle at the start of September.\n\nChairman Mark Tucker said the CEO elect is "an exceptional leader and banker", who has "a track record of leading through change, driving growth, delivering simplification, containing costs and brings a strong focus on execution".\n\n7.17am: FTSE 100 to open higher\n\nThe FTSE 100 is expected to snap out of its two-day losing streak on Wednesday after inflation numbers looked to put pressure on the Bank of England to cut rates sooner than later.\n\nUK inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, rose 0.1% over the month of June, as expected, which meant the annual rise in CPI remained at 2.0% for the second month running, though the forecast was for 1.9%.\n\nCore CPI, which excludes more volatile prices such as food and fuel, also remained at 3.5% in June.\n\nServices sector CPI, a key measure watched by the BoE\'s monetary policy committee as an indicator of persistent inflation, stayed at 5.7%.\n\nSpread-betters tipped the London benchmark for a 20-point gain, after the index lost over 80 points over past two days to close at 8,164.9.\n\nOvernight, Wall Street indices reached new highs, led by the small-cap Russell 2000, up 3.5%, while the Dow Jones advanced 1.85%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the Nasdaq just 0.2% as several tech giants, such as Microsoft, Nvidia, Alphabet and Meta Platforms fell more than 1%.\n\nAsian markets are mixed this morning, with Japan\'s Nikkei and the Shanghi Composite down slightly, but the Hang Seng up and India\'s Sensex flat.', 'source': {'uri': 'proactiveinvestors.co.uk', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Proactiveinvestors UK'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'oliver_haill@proactiveinvestors.co.uk', 'name': 'Oliver Haill', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://cdn.proactiveinvestors.com/eyJidWNrZXQiOiJwYS1jZG4iLCJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRcL05ld3NcL0ltYWdlXC8yMDI0XzA3XC8yMDI0LTA3LTE3LTEyLTUyLTU5LWFjMmY5NmNmMGM5OTNlYjUxODkzNDJiZWIwNGQ4YzEyLmpwZyIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTIwMCwiaGVpZ2h0Ijo2MzAsImZpdCI6ImNvdmVyIn19fQ==', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.06666666666666665, 'wgt': 458920258, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8230115667', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:50:52', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:50:52Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:50:13Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.800000011920929, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/the-greenhouse-effect-how-an-oft-touted-climate-solution-threatens-agricultural-workers/article_0d72dcfe-b92f-5276-a196-26fe50337869.html', 'title': 'The "greenhouse effect": How an oft-touted climate solution threatens agricultural workers', 'body': 'A former greenhouse worker at AppHarvest, who wishes to remain anonymous, poses for a portrait behind a sheet of plastic, Tuesday, July 9, 2024, in Morehead, Ky. "I started getting really sick from the heat. And my body started shutting down on me," this worker said.\n\nBy MELINA WALLING and DORANY PINEDA - Associated Press\n\nMOREHEAD, Ky. (AP) -- To harvest tomatoes, peppers and cucumbers, to clip herbs, to prune and propagate succulents, people work in oppressive heat and humidity. Some wring out shirts soaked with sweat. Some contend with headaches, dizziness and nausea. Some collapse. Some hover on the brink of exhaustion, backs straining, breathing heavily.\n\nMany do so not out in farm fields, but indoors - under the roofs of greenhouses. In structures designed to control the growing environment of plants, some workers described humidity with temperatures sometimes soaring past 100 degrees Fahrenheit (nearly 38 degrees Celsius).\n\n"The heat is unbearable and the humidity equally so," said Estela Martinez, speaking in Spanish of the six years she worked in a nursery in Florida. "I lost too much weight because my T-shirts were coming out soaked, soaked from the heat inside."\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa\'s new café and bakery Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Why is that? Here\'s the lowdown on some Napa head-scratchers Napa County, Hoopes winery file closing arguments in legal clash St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Fight between Le Petit Elephant and Alta Heights neighbors gets personal Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Defendants in Napa double murder delay pleas to Sept. 17\n\nThe number of greenhouse and nursery workers has increased by over 16,000 people in recent years, according to data from the latest U.S. agricultural census. Some work in conventional operations like commercial nurseries, others in buzzy startups that tout indoor agriculture as a climate change solution.\n\nThe data, along with stories of 10 current and former greenhouse workers approached by The Associated Press, shows a growing population of workers who are increasingly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses, injuries and death as global temperatures rise and greenhouses become more popular. They work in a gray area - they\'re both indoor and agricultural workers, but are not always included in efforts to protect the latter.\n\nBut since it is possible to control greenhouse conditions, and many companies include greenhouses in their pitches for the promise of indoor agriculture, workers and researchers want protections and to have them enforced.\n\nIn those suffocating conditions, workers who don\'t get enough time for breaks outside or in cooler environments, whose shifts are not pushed earlier or later in the summer and whose managers ignore their concerns are the most at risk.\n\n"Many times we don\'t leave to cool off (even) for a short while. It\'s not because we wouldn\'t want to do it, but because we\'re scared that they would dismiss us," Eulalia Mendoza said, speaking in Spanish. Mendoza worked in a greenhouse in Oxnard, California for the last three years of her 25-year career in agriculture.\n\n"We don\'t have an option," she said. "That is the reality."\n\nHeat and humidity, a dangerous combination\n\nDuring her time in the industry, Mendoza picked cucumbers in a greenhouse where the temperature could spike between 105 and 115 degrees (41 to 46 C) in the summer, she said. "You\'d come out of there with your clothes drenched in sweat, as if you\'d soaked your clothes in water," she said. The exertion, coupled with the extreme heat and humidity, often lead to heat stress.\n\n"Many of us didn\'t know how to identify the symptoms of heat illness," Mendoza said.\n\nShe recalled a hot day when she felt a headache and nausea before the greenhouse looked yellow. She had stopped sweating and was wheeled outside in a cart meant to carry overheated workers to fresh air. They pressed ice and cold cloths to her head, removed her shoes and the sweatshirt, hat and face cover she wore. When she recovered, they sent her home.\n\n"That happens every day," Mendoza said, adding that the first time she felt heat illness, about five other colleagues sat outside with similar symptoms. The second time, there were about a dozen.\n\nIsabel Rosario Velasco, who works in a greenhouse in San Diego County, described similar symptoms. "When it\'s really hot, your head can hurt and you feel dizzy ... sometimes it feels like you can\'t breathe."\n\nA worker with the now-bankrupt vertical farming startup AppHarvest also recalled fainting from hot greenhouses. The worker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation, said "everything just started closing in on me." He and others said temperatures frequently reached 113 degrees Fahrenheit (45 Celsius). "I stumbled and caught myself, but I had to be sat down and escorted out." Within 20 minutes of entering the greenhouse, another colleague passed out, he said.\n\nHeat combined with humidity makes it harder for sweat to evaporate to cool the body, creating a potentially more dangerous scenario.\n\nWhile people can acclimatize to some of these conditions, the persistent misconception that certain racial groups can better tolerate heat is entirely untrue, said Bharat Jayram Venkat, professor and founding director of the UCLA Heat Lab.\n\nIf anything, Black people, Latinos and others from communities of color are more vulnerable to extreme heat because they\'re more likely to be lower income, not have air conditioning at home, or live in hotter areas, he said.\n\nRebecca Young, director of programs at the nonprofit Farmworker Justice, has heard about farmworker housing that can lack shade, air conditioning and have poor ventilation.\n\nLittle research or regulation, more workers\n\nBetween 2010 and 2019, nursery and greenhouse operations nearly doubled their hiring of H-2A agricultural visa holders, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. But without some legally-binding protections, their ability to speak up about working conditions becomes harder.\n\nThere are no federal heat protections in the U.S. for agricultural workers, nor are there federal guidelines specifically requiring greenhouses to measure temperatures and humidity, though the Biden administration recently proposed a rule for workplaces to address heat.\n\nCalifornia\'s branch of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration recently approved regulations for indoor heat, and several other states have their own rules on heat illness prevention. But enforcement of them can be tricky: for instance, workers are entitled to a 10 to 15-minute break, but that may be too short for them to properly shed and don their gear and so they may stay inside to ensure they\'re back to work on time.\n\nWhen Mendoza worked in a greenhouse, it would take about 10 minutes to walk from her work station to a shaded area for a break, then another two to three minutes to shed her work clothes and plastic covers on her shoes. By then, her break was over. "So what we would normally do is not go outside," she said. "Sometimes we would take our breaks inside the greenhouse... and only go outside for lunch."\n\nOSHA only has in their database two formal complaints about heat stress specifically in greenhouses, one in 2005 and one in 2017. That may reflect workers\' concerns about retaliation if they report life-threatening workplace conditions, said Abigail Kerfoot, senior staff attorney at Centro de los Derechos del Migrante, a migrants\' rights organization. She pointed to what she calls "structural issues" with temporary visas and subcontracting of migrant labor in the United States.\n\nKerfoot said she has seen attempts by greenhouse employers to "distance" themselves "from responsibility for its workers through the use of subcontracting arrangements," which essentially means they\'re not directly responsible for their workers.\n\nBetween 2012 and 2022, 418 people died from work-related exposure to heat across industries, according to data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.\n\nThere is little research documenting the working conditions of greenhouse workers. Many of the studies that do exist are in countries outside of the U.S.\n\nFew trainings for the most vulnerable\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt was the summer of 2020 in Orange County, California when Emily Hernandez started her first job in a greenhouse. She recalled the humidity and "intense heat" she experienced 40 hours a week as she tried to swiftly weed and re-pot the "hundreds upon hundreds" of succulents she was tasked with.\n\nThe pressure to work fast gave her anxiety, and her back often strained from bending over. But the heat, she said, was the worst part.\n\nHernandez said in the five weeks she worked there, she never received heat safety training despite temperatures that could rise up to the high 80s. "It was kind of learning as you go," Hernandez said.\n\nInstead, safety and comfort tips came from colleagues: Bring a fan. And a chair. Keep one water bottle in the freezer and one with you always.\n\n"There was really no concern for safety in that way," Hernandez said. "When I did bring it up, there was a company meeting about not complaining about the heat."\n\nUniversities with greenhouses do things differently. At the University of California, Davis, students, staff and researchers are required to take greenhouse safety trainings that cover heat illness protection, injury reduction, emergency guidance and the federal worker protection standard.\n\nMost of the campus\' greenhouses automatically cool or heat the environment at certain temperatures, according to Bill Werner, lead greenhouse manager for UC Davis\' College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences. On 100-degree days, researchers working in older greenhouses are encouraged to work early mornings, stay hydrated and take breaks in cooler areas. Various complexes also have shade and stations with cold potable water.\n\nWhile research and commercial greenhouses share similar goals of creating optimal growing environments for plants, a major difference is the amount of time people spend in them.\n\nLike Hernandez, agricultural workers often labor eight hours or more a day, five or more days a week inside commercial greenhouses. At UC Davis, people spend an average of 15 minutes to an hour daily inside greenhouses, said Werner, but can be in there for hours if they\'re collecting data or setting up a project.\n\n"I don\'t think I\'ve ever seen anybody here just eight hours straight," he said.\n\nCan greenhouses still be a climate solution?\n\nIn what was supposed to be a "climate-resilient food system," workers say temperatures frequently reached 113 degrees Fahrenheit (45 Celsius). That was inside facilities at AppHarvest, an ambitious startup backed by Martha Stewart with multiple massive tomato greenhouses in rural Kentucky that touted itself as a climate solution.\n\nWorkers say they saw colleagues carried out on makeshift stretchers, and dozens more helped outside on others\' shoulders.\n\n"I started getting really sick from the heat. And my body started shutting down on me," said one worker, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation. "And when I passed out and went home that day, I\'d just laid there, and I was thinking, like, \'I can\'t keep doing this.\'"\n\nIt wasn\'t just summer heat causing these conditions: several AppHarvest workers said the company was riddled with mismanagement. They said there were a couple iterations of a worker orientation, but that it was "boring and breezy" and didn\'t adequately cover greenhouse safety. Some said they sometimes couldn\'t keep water bottles in the greenhouse because they might knock against the plants and damage the fruit, or because it looked bad when visitors came through on tours.\n\nOne anonymous contract worker formerly with AppHarvest, speaking in Spanish, said the company\'s greenhouses were "plagued by rats."\n\nAppHarvest, which has since declared bankruptcy, did not respond to a detailed list of questions about these problems, though their 2021 sustainability report featured a section devoted to employee wages, benefits, career paths and safety. "Nothing can be grown without the people that we have," the report stated, quoting the senior manager of environmental health and safety at the time. "We must protect our greatest asset, which is people."\n\nOther indoor growing companies maintain that with the right management, greenhouse growing is a promising climate solution.\n\n"You\'ve got climate change that is just exacerbating issues for outdoor growers," said Steve Bradley, president of Cox Farms, a greenhouse-based indoor growing company. He says that with greenhouses sheltering crops from extreme heat, his company has "decoupled the growing from these external weather patterns."\n\nBradley said that his modernized greenhouses have the technology to be completely climate controlled.\n\nDay temperatures in their current greenhouses range from 70 to 85 degrees Fahrenheit (about 21 to 29.5 Celsius), and humidity levels average about 80%, according to the company. Summer brings temperatures between 82 to 85 degrees Fahrenheit (about 28 to 29.5 Celsius), but when equipment fails, it can soar to 95 degrees. To account for excessive heat, they adjust workers\' schedules, starting them earlier in the morning, breaking mid-day during peak heat, and returning in the evening as temperatures cool, the company said.\n\nAaron Fields, vice president of agriculture at greenhouse-based vertical farming company Eden Green in Texas, said that temperatures in their greenhouses regularly hover between 70 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit (21 to 27 Celsius) but can get hotter during the summer, sometimes above 90 (32 degrees Celsius). A few years ago, they shifted their workers\' summer schedules to earlier in the day so they aren\'t working inside at the hottest hours.\n\nFields added that it\'s important to be trained to identify symptoms of heat stress, to work in a buddy system and to stay hydrated.\n\nHe thinks the startup culture of "high-tech" greenhouses, which can include leaders and founders without prior farming experience, has led some to miss the importance of working conditions. "Unfortunately, some of these were safety protections or the things that go unnoticed ... those became the last priorities," he said.\n\nIt\'s all about establishing rules to protect workers, explained Young from Farmworker Justice. When temperatures are monitored; when workers get adequate breaks, water and training; when they aren\'t trapped inside with pesticide residues too soon after application, then growing in greenhouses can be considered sustainable for humans and agriculture alike.\n\n"A greenhouse can be a very healthy place to work," Young said. "It\'s sort of thinking about, how can we interact with the climate around us in a way that keeps people and the food that we\'re eating healthy and safe?"\n\nWhile technology and good practices exist to ensure workers are safe and comfortable in greenhouses, many can\'t chose the environments they spend much of their days in.\n\n"We don\'t have the option to pick our work," Mendoza said. "We have to accept what there is."\n\nPineda reported from Los Angeles.\n\nThe Associated Press\' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP\'s standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. (AP) -- Many farms, from vertical farming startups to traditional specialty crop growers, are marketing greenhouses as a way to shelter crops from climate extremes. But overlooked are the experiences of workers inside, who may swelter under high heat and humidity.\n\nThe number of greenhouse and nursery workers has increased by over 16,000 in recent years, according to the latest U.S. agricultural census, and there are still no federal heat rules to protect them.\n\nThe data, along with stories of current and former greenhouse workers, shows a growing population of people increasingly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses, injuries and death as global temperatures rise and greenhouses become more popular.\n\nHere\'s what to know from AP\'s report.\n\nHeat and humidity, a dangerous combination People are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa\'s new café and bakery Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Why is that? She described being drenched in sweat and suffering from heat illness -- headaches, nausea, ceasing to sweat.\n\nOther workers across the U.S. described losing weight, dizziness and fainting from extreme heat.\n\nIn those conditions, workers who don\'t get enough breaks in cooler environments, whose shifts are not pushed earlier or later in the summer and whose managers ignore their concerns are the most at risk.\n\nLittle research or regulation, more workers\n\nBetween 2010 and 2019, nursery and greenhouse operations nearly doubled their hiring of H-2A agricultural visa holders. For instance, workers are entitled to a 10 to 15-minute break, but that may be too short to shed and don their gear, so they may stay inside to ensure they\'re back to work on time.\n\nThe Occupational Safety and Health Administration has two complaints about heat stress specifically in greenhouses, in 2005 and 2017. The low number of documented complaints may reflect workers\' concerns about retaliation if they report workplace conditions, said Abigail Kerfoot with Centro de los Derechos del Migrante, a migrants\' rights organization.\n\nFew trainings for the vulnerable\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nSome current and former greenhouse workers said they didn\'t get training to identify symptoms of or protect themselves from heat.\n\nEmily Hernandez, who worked for a summer in a greenhouse in Orange County, said she never received heat safety training despite temperatures that could rise up to the high 80s.\n\n"When I did bring it up, there was a company meeting about not complaining about the heat," she said.\n\nAt the University of California, Davis, students, staff and researchers are required to take greenhouse safety trainings that cover heat illness protection, injury reduction, emergency guidance and the federal worker protection standard.\n\nOn 100-degree days, researchers working in older greenhouses are encouraged to work early mornings, stay hydrated and take breaks in cooler areas.\n\nGreenhouses as a climate solution\n\nIn what was supposed to be a "climate-resilient food system," workers say temperatures frequently reached 113 degrees Fahrenheit (45 Celsius) inside facilities at the now-bankrupt AppHarvest, a startup with greenhouses in Kentucky that touted itself as a climate solution.\n\nWorkers say they saw colleagues carried out on makeshift stretchers, and dozens more helped outside on others\' shoulders.\n\n"I started getting really sick from the heat. And my body started shutting down on me," said one worker.\n\nIndoor growing companies maintain that with the right management, greenhouse growing is a promising climate solution. To account for excessive heat, some say they adjust workers\' schedules, starting them earlier in the morning or later in the day when temperatures are cooler.\n\nAaron Fields, vice president of agriculture at greenhouse-based vertical farming company Eden Green, thinks the startup culture of "high-tech" greenhouses, which can include leaders and founders without prior farming experience, has led some to miss the importance of working conditions.\n\nBut Rebecca Young with the nonprofit Farmworker Justice said greenhouses can be healthy places to work, beginning with establishing worker protections. When temperatures are monitored; when workers get adequate breaks, water and training, then growing in greenhouses can be sustainable for humans and agriculture alike.\n\n"It\'s sort of thinking about, how can we interact with the climate around us in a way that keeps people and the food that we\'re eating healthy and safe?" she said.\n\nThe Associated Press receives support from the Walton Family Foundation for coverage of water and environmental policy. {'uri': '8230112367', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:48:10', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:48:10Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:47:48Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6549019813537598, 'url': 'https://www.theregister.com/2024/07/17/what_did_microsoft_promise_cispe/', 'title': 'What did Microsoft promise CISPE in its settlement?', 'body': 'Analysis Microsoft\'s deal to settle an antitrust complaint taken to the European Commission by a group of cloud providers is good for Microsoft, but no so meaningful for enterprise customers, says a well respected analyst.\n\nThe Cloud Infrastructure Services Providers in Europe (CISPE) organization, which represents 27 members, an issue that it had filed with the EC in November 2022.\n\nMicrosoft\'s maneuvering is undoubtedly impressive. For a relatively small payout -- we\'ve seen claimed figures ranging from 10 million euros to 30 million US dollars -- the company managed to get CISPE\'s complaint over alleged anticompetitive behavior withdrawn. AWS, Google, and Alibaba were excluded from the settlement.\n\nThe complaint centered on the higher cost of running Microsoft software in public clouds outside of Microsoft Azure.\n\nSome onlookers are unimpressed by the deal. Directions on Microsoft analyst Wes Miller said, "At the end of the day, the settlement is nothing."\n\n"It won\'t affect so-called listed providers and just promises to give a few Azure exclusives to the smaller \'authorized outsourcers.\' It\'s unclear what this settlement actually resolves other than a legal threat."\n\nThe cloud giants -- Microsoft, AWS, and Google -- enjoy market dominance in Europe despite regular complaints by regulators. However, running Microsoft software on the likes of listed providers that include AWS and Google is not covered by the settlement. Instead, European cloud providers will -- if Microsoft sticks to its nine-month promise -- get an enhanced version of Azure Stack HCI for European cloud providers dubbed Azure HCI Stack for Hosters.\n\nSources with knowledge of the matter told The Register earlier this week that a higher value deal was on the table from Google to keep the complaint alive, but it was rejected in favor of Microsoft by CISPE members, who apparently valued the CISPE\'s independence over half a billion euros\' worth of credits spread over five years alongside a more considerable lump sum payment upfront.\n\nMary Jo Foley of Directions on Microsoft wrote, "It\'s unclear if there are other hidden terms in the agreement," which is a fair point to raise considering what CISPE members apparently turned down in favor of Microsoft\'s deal. Another source described Google\'s offer as staggering and laughed, "When did Google become a not-for-profit company?"\n\nOur source also noted that the settlement did not address every issue, with question marks still surrounding services such as Microsoft Entra. However, they did describe the settlement as a significant step forward in solving the problem of licensing Microsoft\'s productivity software for some cloud providers. Even if AWS and Google were notable exceptions.\n\nAccording to our source, Microsoft has a "different relationship" with its rival tech giants compared to CISPE\'s members and their comparatively smaller European market share. ®', 'source': {'uri': 'theregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'theregister.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://regmedia.co.uk/2022/02/21/shutterstock_microsoft.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9736252', 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458920090, 'relevance': 113}
{'uri': '8230112209', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:48:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:48:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:47:42Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8549019694328308, 'url': 'https://mcdowellnews.com/opinion/column/tyler-cowen-why-is-sweden-paying-grandparents-to-babysit-economist-says-its-worth-a-try/article_aaeae083-7206-5f2f-b3b0-14fe4428c5d7.html', 'title': "Tyler Cowen: Why is Sweden paying grandparents to babysit? Economist says it's worth a try", 'body': 'As Sweden attends its first NATO summit as a member, FRANCE 24\'s Nadia Massih spoke to Tobias Billström, Swedish Foreign Minister.\n\nAt first glance, the policy sounds absurd, especially to many Americans: In Sweden, grandparents are now eligible for government subsidies to babysit their grandchildren.\n\nAs a proud grandparent, I would be willing to pay to babysit my grandkids. (I don\'t have to, but I would.) It would feel wrong to accept government money for my services.\n\nAnd even in the Swedish context, the program seems excessive. The country has long had first-rate and well-subsidized child-care facilities, which is another reason not to pay grandparents anything, and Sweden already has high levels of government spending and taxation. Is this additional benefit -- and expenditure -- really what it needs?\n\nBut sometimes even apparently foolish ideas have such compelling rationales that you begin to rethink whether they\'re foolish at all. These are often the cases that require the hardest thinking.\n\nPeople are also reading... McDowell County Schools moving principals at West Middle, Eastfield and Foothills school McDowell leaders seek land for new animal shelter McDowell County to host country, bluegrass festivals in August McDowell High athlete appointed to NC Student-Athlete Advisory Council Picasso Keaton, a former WSSU football player, dies in a car crash Marion NC man charged with breaking into home, assault Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report McDowell ministry launches program to improve health of those in need Nebo man charged with meth possession Marion NC man\'s charges upgraded to felony after assault on 79-year-old Asheville hospital performs new heart procedure Hickory pastor has a license to practice law. Plus, she\'s been on \'Jeopardy\' NC high school student on robotics trip drowns at Ocean Isle Beach 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating What is DEI? Former Lenoir-Rhyne administrator talks about diversity, inclusion at university\n\nIf you look at Sweden\'s policy closely, it adheres pretty well to some basic economic principles: namely, the notion of "Pareto improvements," which benefit all parties involved.\n\nStart with the fact that Swedish parents currently receive extensive paid leave on the birth of a child, and so it can be said they are already paid to look after their children. Whether you agree with that policy, it is longstanding and well-established. Take it as a given.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nNow imagine that you are an ambitious Swedish doctor or lawyer, climbing the career ladder, and are self-aware enough to realize you do not always have entirely the right degree of natural patience necessary for parenting. In that case, you might prefer to go back to work following the birth of your child. Under the status quo, you could not work and draw your normal salary and still get the full child-care benefit, even though some child benefits are paid automatically.\n\nSo the system has some potential inefficiency. You may stay at home just to get the money, even when an alternate arrangement might be better for everyone.\n\nNow add grandparents to this equation. If the grandparents can be paid to take care of your child, all of a sudden the extended family as a whole doesn\'t lose the money by having the parent go back to work. Instead, that money is transferred to the grandparents, so the work disincentive is diminished.\n\nAnd economists will tell you that the parents and grandparents can do their own settling up. If the grandparents are well-to-do, for instance, and eager to spend time with their grandkids, they might funnel some of that money back to the parents or the child, either directly or indirectly. In some cases, on net, the grandparents may not end up getting paid anything at all.\n\nIn essence, you can think of this policy as a model designed to maximize gains from trade.\n\nOne side effect is that, to the extent the parent who returns to work is a high earner, government tax revenue will increase. That will help pay for the policy, partially if not entirely.\n\nThe logic for this policy may hold all the more for single parents. In that case, the costs of giving up work may be even higher. That\'s because on a single income, climbing the career ladder and investing in future earnings will be all the more important. Enlisting aid from grandparents may also be more necessary, given the higher burdens on a single caregiver. A defender of the policy would cite these accommodative benefits, whereas a critic might allege they encourage single parenthood too much.\n\nMore broadly, fiscal conservatives might point out that the policy still costs some money upfront, while social conservatives might argue that it commodifies family relationships. The policy\'s supporters, on the other hand, might note that it can help some people get back to work and also make the grandparents happier. The children might benefit, too.\n\nI am still unsure if this policy is a good idea, though it has stronger virtues and benefits than I first thought. But I am all the more certain of one final lesson: Framing is everything. The very same policy, described in different terms, can sound eminently reasonable or badly out of whack. Keep that in mind next time you are tempted to render a quick verdict on someone else\'s idea.\n\nCowen is a Bloomberg columnist, professor of economics at George Mason University and host of the Marginal Revolution blog.\n\n___\n\nCatch the latest in Opinion\n\nGet opinion pieces, letters and editorials sent directly to your inbox weekly!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'mcdowellnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'McDowellNews.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/mcdowellnews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/ae/aaeae083-7206-5f2f-b3b0-14fe4428c5d7/6697b3ceed80f.preview.jpg?crop=1765%2C927%2C0%2C123&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738640', 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458920086, 'relevance': 31}
{'uri': '8230110737', 'lang': 'ell', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:48:05', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:48:05Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:46:35Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7607843279838562, 'url': 'https://www.skai.gr/news/finance/tourkia-anodos-157-tou-ploutou-tis-para-ton-ypsilo-plithorismo', 'title': 'Ελλάδα: Φτωχότεροι οι Έλληνες κατά 11% σε διάστημα 2008-2023', 'body': 'Στην αύξηση του μέσου όρου του πλούτου ανά ενήλικα μετά την Τουρκία ακολουθούν Ρωσία και Κατάρ\n\nΠτώση 11% έχει καταγράψει κατά μέσο όρο ο πλούτος στην Ελλάδα την περίοδο 2008 - 2023, όπως προκύπτει από έκθεση της ελβετικής τράπεζας UBS, για τον παγκόσμιο πλούτο (Global Wealth Report 2024).\n\nΑκόμα μεγαλύτερη είναι η πτώση του διάμεσου πλούτου -που ως όρος περιγράφει καλύτερα το κέντρο κατανομής του πλούτου- ο οποίος σημείωσε μείωση 31%. Με άλλα λόγια, οι πλούσιοι γίνονται πλουσιότεροι και οι φτωχοί φτωχότεροι.\n\nΗ Τουρκία την ίδια στιγμή "έφυγε μπροστά", αφήνοντας πίσω μίλια μακριά τις υπόλοιπες χώρες στην ετήσια παγκόσμια κατάταξη πλούτου. Το γεγονός αυτό προκαλεί έκπληξη, σύμφωνα με το CNBC δεδομένου του πληθωρισμού της, που βρίσκεται στα ύψη.\n\nΕιδικότερα, όπως έγραψε η ελβετική τράπεζα UBS στην έκθεσή της για τον παγκόσμιο πλούτο (Global Wealth Report 2024), "η Τουρκία ξεχωρίζει με εκπληκτική άνοδο πάνω από 157% του κατανεμημένου πλούτου ανά ενήλικα στο διάστημα μεταξύ 2022 και 2023, αφήνοντας τα υπόλοιπα κράτη αρκετά πίσω".\n\nΣτην αύξηση του μέσου όρου του πλούτου ανά ενήλικα, την Τουρκία ακολουθούν η Ρωσία και το Κατάρ με σχεδόν 20% και η Νότια Αφρική με άνοδο πάνω από 16%. Στις ΗΠΑ ο μέσος όρος του πλούτου ανά ενήλικα αυξήθηκε κατά 2,5%.\n\nΟ πληθωρισμός στην Τουρκία, ωστόσο, έχει παραμείνει κολλημένος στο ιδιαίτερα υψηλό ποσοστό του 72%. Οι περίπου 85 εκατ. πολίτες της χώρας έχουν έρθει αντιμέτωποι με δραματική πτώση της αγοραστικής τους δύναμης τα τελευταία χρόνια.\n\nΤα τελευταία πέντε χρόνια, η αξία της λίρας έχει υποχωρήσει σε ποσοστό 83% έναντι του δολαρίου και η ισοτιμία ήταν 33 λίρες ανά δολάριο στις 09:07 της Τετάρτης.\n\nΩστόσο, για τους Τούρκους που διαθέτουν ακίνητη περιουσία, ο πλούτος αυξήθηκε, καθώς ο πληθωρισμός έδωσε ώθηση προς τα πάνω στην αξία αυτής της ιδιοκτησίας.\n\nΗ έκθεση της UBS ορίζει την καθαρή αξία του πλούτου ανά ενήλικα ως "την αξία των χρηματοοικονομικών περιουσιακών στοιχείων συν την ακίνητη περιουσία μείον τα χρέη των ιδιοκτητών".\n\n"Με έναν τρόπο, ο υψηλός πληθωρισμός εξηγεί τον λόγο της τόσο μεγάλης αύξησης με όρους τοπικού νομίσματος, συγκριτικά με τις άλλες χώρες, δεδομένου ότι ο πλούτος αποτιμάται με ονομαστικούς όρους", ανέφερε στο CNBC ο Samuel Adams, οικονομολόγος της UBS Global Wealth Management.\n\n"Αν ο πληθωρισμός είναι πολύ υψηλός, η αξία της ακίνητης περιουσίας τείνει να ανεβαίνει αναλογικά με τον πληθωρισμό, αν όχι γρηγορότερα", προσέθεσε. "Ως εκ τούτου οι ιδιοκτήτες ακινήτων ή όσοι διαθέτουν μετοχές, που επίσης έχουν τάση να αποδίδουν ανάλογα σε τέτοια περιβάλλοντα, βλέπουν τον πλούτο τους να συγκεντρώνεται λίγο γρηγορότερα".\n\n"Φυσικά, αυτό δεν σημαίνει ότι όλοι επωφελούνται το ίδιο", συμπλήρωσε ο Adams. "Αν δεν διαθέτει κάποιος ακίνητα περιουσιακά στοιχεία και αν η αύξηση του μισθού του δεν μπορεί να ακολουθήσει τον ρυθμό του πληθωρισμού, θα επηρεαστεί αρνητικά από την κατάσταση".\n\n"Φαινόμενο του νομίσματος", σύμφωνα με την έκθεση της UBS, είναι αυτό που αλλάζει τα στοιχεία για την αύξηση του πλούτου με όρους τοπικού νομίσματος. Είναι συχνά σημαντικά διαφορετικά συγκριτικά με αυτά που παρουσιάζονται σε όρους δολαρίου.\n\n"Η ήδη εξαιρετική ανάπτυξη της Τουρκίας, που σημειώνει ποσοστό πάνω από 63% σε δολάρια ΗΠΑ, υπερδιπλασιάζεται σε σχεδόν 158% σε τουρκικές λίρες", ανέφερε. Άλλα παραδείγματα στην έκθεση περιελάμβαναν την Ιαπωνία, η οποία σε όρους δολαρίου έχει σημειώσει λιγότερο από 2% μέση αύξηση του πλούτου ανά ενήλικα μεταξύ 2022-23, αλλά σε τοπικό νόμισμα η αύξηση αυτή ήταν 9%.\n\nΑξιολογώντας τη μέση αύξηση του πλούτου των χωρών μεταξύ των ετών 2008 και 2023, "η πιο εντυπωσιακή εξέλιξη σημειώθηκε στην Τουρκία", έγραψε η UBS, "όπου ο μέσος πλούτος ανά ενήλικα αυτή τη χρονική περίοδο αυξήθηκε κατά 1.708% σε τοπικό νόμισμα".\n\nΟ επικεφαλής οικονομολόγος της UBS Global Wealth Management, Paul Donovan, επεσήμανε ότι το να είσαι πλούσιος σε περιουσιακά στοιχεία δεν σημαίνει απαραίτητα ότι είσαι πλούσιος και σε μετρητά στην Τουρκία. Θα μπορούσε, μάλιστα, στην πραγματικότητα να σημαίνει και το αντίθετο.\n\n"Όσον αφορά το βιοτικό επίπεδο και όχι τον πλούτο, είναι επίσης σημαντικό να θυμάστε ότι εάν έχετε ένα σπίτι, η αξία του σπιτιού σας έχει αυξηθεί, αλλά συγχρόνως ο πραγματικός σας μισθός μπορεί να έχει επηρεαστεί αρνητικά. Έτσι μπορεί να είστε πλούσιοι σε περιουσιακά στοιχεία και φτωχοί σε μετρητά", τόνισε ο Donovan την περασμένη εβδομάδα.\n\nΔιαβάστε τις Ειδήσεις σήμερα και ενημερωθείτε για τα πρόσφατα νέα.\n\nΑκολουθήστε το Skai.gr στο Google News και μάθετε πρώτοι όλες τις ειδήσεις.', 'source': {'uri': 'skai.gr', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'ΣΚΑΪ'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://cdn.skai.gr/sites/default/files/styles/article_16_9/public/2024-07/ploutos.jpg?itok=JGWfAXaW', 'eventUri': 'ell-946356', 'sentiment': None, 'wgt': 458920085, 'relevance': 21}

Economist says it's worth a try", 'body': 'As Sweden attends its first NATO summit as a member, FRANCE 24\'s Nadia Massih spoke to Tobias Billström, Swedish Foreign Minister.\n\nAt first glance, the policy sounds absurd, especially to many Americans: In Sweden, grandparents are now eligible for government subsidies to babysit their grandchildren.\n\nAs a proud grandparent, I would be willing to pay to babysit my grandkids. Whether you agree with that policy, it is longstanding and well-established. Take it as a given.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nNow imagine that you are an ambitious Swedish doctor or lawyer, climbing the career ladder, and are self-aware enough to realize you do not always have entirely the right degree of natural patience necessary for parenting. In that case, you might prefer to go back to work following the birth of your child. Under the status quo, you could not work and draw your normal salary and still get the full child-care benefit, even though some child benefits are paid automatically.\n\nSo the system has some potential inefficiency. You may stay at home just to get the money, even when an alternate arrangement might be better for everyone.\n\nNow add grandparents to this equation. If the grandparents can be paid to take care of your child, all of a sudden the extended family as a whole doesn\'t lose the money by having the parent go back to work. Instead, that money is transferred to the grandparents, so the work disincentive is diminished.\n\nAnd economists will tell you that the parents and grandparents can do their own settling up. If the grandparents are well-to-do, for instance, and eager to spend time with their grandkids, they might funnel some of that money back to the parents or the child, either directly or indirectly. In some cases, on net, the grandparents may not end up getting paid anything at all.\n\nIn essence, you can think of this policy as a model designed to maximize gains from trade.\n\nOne side effect is that, to the extent the parent who returns to work is a high earner, government tax revenue will increase. That will help pay for the policy, partially if not entirely.\n\nThe logic for this policy may hold all the more for single parents. In that case, the costs of giving up work may be even higher. That\'s because on a single income, climbing the career ladder and investing in future earnings will be all the more important. Enlisting aid from grandparents may also be more necessary, given the higher burdens on a single caregiver. A defender of the policy would cite these accommodative benefits, whereas a critic might allege they encourage single parenthood too much.\n\nMore broadly, fiscal conservatives might point out that the policy still costs some money upfront, while social conservatives might argue that it commodifies family relationships. The policy\'s supporters, on the other hand, might note that it can help some people get back to work and also make the grandparents happier. The children might benefit, too.\n\nI am still unsure if this policy is a good idea, though it has stronger virtues and benefits than I first thought. But I am all the more certain of one final lesson: Framing is everything. The very same policy, described in different terms, can sound eminently reasonable or badly out of whack. Keep that in mind next time you are tempted to render a quick verdict on someone else\'s idea.\n\nCowen is a Bloomberg columnist, professor of economics at George Mason University and host of the Marginal Revolution blog.\n\n___\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nCatch the latest in Opinion\n\nGet opinion pieces, letters and editorials sent directly to your inbox weekly!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'nwitimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'nwi.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'assets@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'assets', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'tncms@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'tncms', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/nwitimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/88/288855c6-31c1-598d-8702-2f31192efcef/6697b3cfe889f.preview.jpg?crop=1765%2C927%2C0%2C123&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738640', 'sentiment': 0.1058823529411765, 'wgt': 458920081, 'relevance': 38}

présumées.\n\nEn septembre, le gendarme français de la concurrence avait déjà mené une perquisition chez l'entreprise à Paris.\n\nContacté par l'AFP, Nvidia n'a pas souhaité faire de artificielle.\n\n'Il est essentiel que le fonctionnement concurrentiel du secteur soit favorable à l'innovation et permette la présence d'une multiplicité d'acteurs', a ainsi pointé l'institution dans {'uri': '8230110725', 'lang': 'ind', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:47:03', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:47:03Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:46:34Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5529412031173706, 'url': 'https://industri.kontan.co.id/news/ada-revisi-aturan-pelabelan-bpa-pada-amdk-begini-kata-aspadin', 'title': 'Ada Revisi Aturan Pelabelan BPA Pada AMDK, Begini Kata Aspadin', 'body': 'Reporter: Vina Elvira | Editor: Tri Sulistiowati\n\nKONTAN.CO.ID - JAKARTA. Asosiasi Pengusaha Air Minum Dalam Kemasan Indonesia (Aspadin) menilai revisi Peraturan BPOM tentang Label Pangan Olahan pada Air Minum Dalam Kemasan (AMDK) akan memberatkan para pelaku usaha.\n\nKetua Aspadin Rachmat Hidayat mengatakan, mengenai peratauran pelabelan yang baru diterbitkan BPOM memang akan memberatkan pelaku usaha, terutama produsen AMDK skala kecil dan menengah. Hal ini karena akan ada tambahan biaya dan proses pelabelan yang besar.\n\n"Hal ini juga mungkin yang menjadi pertimbangan BPOM sehingga baru mewajibkan pelabelan ini 4 tahun setelah peraturan tersebut diterbitkan," ungkap Rachmat, kepada KONTAN, Rabu (17/7).\n\nDi sisi lain, Aspadin menggarisbawahi bahwa semua AMDK dalam kemasan apapun adalah aman selama memiliki izin edar dari BPOM.\n\nBaca Juga: Sambut Positif Aturan Pelabelan BPA, YLKI: Industri AMDK Harus Siapkan Upaya Mitigasi\n\nDia menjelaskan, AMDK dikemas dalam berbagai macam kemasan yang diizinkan oleh BPOM sesuai peraturan yang berlaku.\n\nBPOM menjaga keamanan kemasan pangan melalui penerapan ambang batas migrasi kemasan pangan yang diatur bagi semua jenis kemasan pangan yang diedarkan di Indonesia.\n\nDi dalam peraturan tentang kemasan pangan dari BPOM, tercantum bahwa semua jenis kemasan pangan memiliki potensi migrasi dari zat kimia yang dikandungnya, seperti BPA pada bahan PC atau EG DEG dan Asetildehida pada bahan PET.\n\nApabila suatu jenis kemasan produk memenuhi ambang batas migrasi yang diatur BPOM, maka BPOM akan mengeluarkan izin edar yang menyatakan bahwa produk tersebut aman dikonsumsi.\n\n"Ini artinya semua AMDK yang sudah memiliki izin edar dari BPOM dan dijual di masyarakat adalah aman untuk dikonsumsi," jelasnya.\n\nUntuk diketahui, (BPOM) menerbitkan perubahan aturan terkait label pangan olahan berdasarkan kajian risiko Bisfenol A (BPA) pada air minum dalam kemasan (AMDK).\n\nPada peraturan terbaru, BPOM mewajibkan pencantuman potensi bahaya BPA pada air minum dalam kemasan yang menggunakan kemasan polikarbonat.\n\nBaca Juga: Kemasan AMDK Kok Beragam? Mana Yang Paling Aman?\n\nSelanjutnya: Perry Warjiyo Ungkap Alasan Bank Indonesia Pertahankan BI Rate di Level 6,25%\n\nMenarik Dibaca: HP Jatuh ke Air? Na konferenciji za medije Brnabić je dodala da imamo odličan start, pre svega zahvaljujući srpskoj kompaniji "Eleven es", koja proizvodi LFP litijumske baterije, najnovu generaciju.\n\n"Imamo naš litijum, imamo srpsku kompaniju koja proizvodi litijumske baterije, imamo Stelantis koja proizvodi električno vozilo. Sami će dolaziti proizvođači katoda, dolaziće drugi proizvođači automobila, zato što će im ovde biti najkonkurentnije da proizvode. Šteta što ne možemo oko te stvari da se ujedinimo i da kažemo ljudi, građani Republike Srbije, evo jedna stvar koju je neko pokrenuo, mi ne sporimo da su oni pokrenuli. Mi sporimo da oni kažu sada da nikakve veze nemaju sa tim", rekla je ona.\n\nBrnabić je još jednom pozvala sve da zajedno razgovaraju i o životnoj sredini i svemu što je za dobrobit građana. "Dajte da vidimo kako da uspostavimo dodatne kontrole i mehanizme. Kako da uspostavimo dodatne mehanizme, da svi zajedno povučemo, da privučemo što više investitora u Srbiju. Umesto ovde što svaki dan raspravljamo da li je crno-crno, a nije belo ili je belo crno. Jer to je ono što radimo", rekla je ona.\n\nBrnabić je dodala da je i kupovna moć građana od 2012. godine do 2024. godine skočila za 30 odsto, a da sada sluša "predavanja" od ljudi za vreme čije vlasti je prosečna plata bila 330 evra, nezaposlenost 26 odsto, nezaposlenost mladih preko 51 odsto. "Sada je nezaposlenost devet odsto, a prosečna plata 825 evra", naglasila je ona.\n\nBrnabić se osvnula i na "moralno sakaćenje" o kojem je govorio Dragan Đilas i dodala da je rijaliti program u Srbiju doveo upravo on. Govoreći o nacionalnim frekvencijama i njihovoj dodeli, Brnabić je rekla da su i za vreme demokratske vlasti iste televizije imale nacionalnu pokrivenost i da im tada to nije smetalo, prenosi Tanjug.\n\n//= __(\'Enter the code from above\') ?> //= md5($code) ?> //= $code ?>\n\nPošaljite komentar\n\nMolimo vas da sе u komеntarima držitе tеmе tеksta. Марјановић)\n\nSREMSKA MITROVICA - Pripadnici Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova u Inđiji, u saradnji sa Poreskom policijom, podneće krivičnu prijavu nadležnom tužilaštvu protiv pedesetosmogodišnjeg muškarca, zbog postojanja osnova sumnje da je izvršio krivično delo nedozvoljen promet akciznih proizvoda.\n\nPrilikom kontrole "sitroena" kojim je upravljao osumnjičeni, policija je u prtljažniku automobila pronašla 655 litara dizel goriva, za koje nije imao račun, saopštila je PU Sremska Mitrovica. {'uri': '2024-07-424878542', 'lang': 'srp', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:46:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:46:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:46:39Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.politika.rs/sr/clanak/623469/Dojce-vele-Nemacka-gradi-svoju-prvu-rafineriju-litijuma-u-Biterfeldu', 'title': '"Dojče vele": Nemačka gradi svoju prvu rafineriju litijuma u Biterfeldu', 'body': '"Dojče vele": Nemačka gradi svoju prvu rafineriju litijuma u Biterfeldu\n\nЕксплоатација бакра и злата из рудника у Монголији (Фото/ "Рио Тинто")\n\nBON - Evropa je zavisna od Kine kada je reč o litijumu, zbog čega se u Nemačkoj gradi prva i verovatno najveća rafinerija za preradu te sirovine na Starom kontinentu. Kako piše "Dojče vele" Evropa na putu ka "zelenoj budućnosti" ima problem - industriji su potrebne sirovine, a da bi se napredovalo u proizvodnji baterija, sirovine kao što je litijum od suštinskog su značaja.\n\nMeđutim, navodi se, hemijska prerada sirovina u materijale pogodne za baterije je komplikovana i zato bi nova litijumska rafinerija u Biterfeldu na istoku Nemačke mogla da postane ključ za nove lance snabdevanja i prva te vrste u Evropi.\n\nTrenutno, u frankfurtskoj laboratoriji kompanije "AMG litijum", hemičari testiraju i prate procese koje su razvili za preradu litijum-hidroksida, traže načine za uklanjanje nečistoća iz sirovine, a ono što smisle u laboratoriji, kasnije će se reprodukovati u industrijskom procesu.\n\nDojče vele piše da prerada litijuma u toj firmi počinje u Brazilu, iskopavanjem spodumena, vrste kamena koji sadrži dragoceni litijum, a koji se u Brazilu drobi i prerađuje. "U prvoj fazi, brodom šaljemo spodumen-koncentrat u Kinu. Razlog za to je što za sada nema druge rafinerije koja može da preradi taj materijal", objašnjava za "Dojče vele" Štefan Šreder predsednik upravnog odbora firme "AMG litijum".\n\nDodaje da se zatim iz Kine tehnički nedovršen proizvod vraća nazad u nemački Biterfeld, gde se prerađuje do konačnog kvaliteta potrebnog za baterije, što je mesto gde bi trebalo da bude podignuta nova rafinerija. "AMG litijum" tu priprema industrijsku proizvodnju, između ostalog i zato što tu ima mesta za planirano širenje pogona, a još uvek se finalizuju detalji verovatno najveće litijumske rafinerije u Evropi.\n\nTa rafinerija će u početku proizvoditi čak 20.000 tona litijum-hidroksida godišnje. Međutim, zbog pada cena litijumskih proizvoda, investiranje je postalo teže.\n\n"Trenutno su ljudi veoma oprezni kada je reč o ulaganju novca u litijumske projekte. Na aktuelnom nivou cena teško je opravdati investiciju" kaže Šreder.\n\nZa ovo postrojenje AMG je dobio 5,5 miliona evra od nemačke pokrajine Saksonije-Anhalt, navodi DV i dodaje da i neke druge evropske vlade žele da obezbede subvencije za izgradnju sopstvene infrastrukture za preradu važne sirovine.\n\nKako se dalje navodi, nedavno je stupio na snagu Evropski zakon o tzv. kritičnim sirovinama, koji bi trebalo da smanji zavisnosti EU u lancima snabdevanja i u kome se postavlja cilj da se u Evropskoj uniji do 2030. godine 10 odsto materijala vadi, 40 odsto prerađuje i 15 odsto reciklira, a plan je da nikad više od 65 odsto neke sirovine ne dolazi iz jedne jedine zemlje-snabdevača.\n\nDojče vele ističe da će litijumska rafinerija AMG u Nemačkoj verovatno doprineti postizanju tih ciljeva, kao i da su prvi ugovori sa kupcima širom Evrope već potpisani, prenosi Tanjug.\n\n//= __(\'Enter the code from above\') ?> //= md5($code) ?> //= $code ?>\n\nPošaljite komentar\n\nMolimo vas da sе u komеntarima držitе tеmе tеksta. Google and Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT)'s cloud divisions are offering Chinese companies access to Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA)'s AI chips by providing data center services in locations outside China, the Information reported on Wednesday.\n\nThe Biden administration has taken measures to prevent firms in China from using U.S. technology for artificial intelligence, including advanced semiconductors, as the burgeoning sector raises security concerns.\n\nMicrosoft, Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL), Nvidia and the Department of Commerce did not immediately respond to Reuters requests for comment.\n\nThe Biden administration has proposed requiring cloud companies to determine whether foreign entities are accessing data centers in the United States to train AI models, U.S. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo told Reuters in January.\n\nMicrosoft offers server rental services, including those with Nvidia's A100 and H100 chips, to Chinese customers through data centers outside China, the Information reported, citing an employee of the Windows maker with knowledge of the services and a person directly involved in the sales.\n\nGoogle lets customers in China use servers based outside of mainland China, and is confident that its offerings comply with U.S. export controls, the publication said, citing a person familiar with the matter.", 'source': {'uri': 'investing.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Investing.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://i-invdn-com.investing.com/trkd-images/LYNXMPEK6G0I9_M.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9740871', 'sentiment': 0.2862745098039217, 'wgt': 458919991, 'relevance': 80}
